title: Dow down nearly 500 points as bond yields hit 2-year highs, Goldman earnings disappoint
text:
A blockbuster tech deal was also in the spotlight, after Microsoft Corp. MSFT said it had reached an agreement to acquire Activision Blizzard Inc. ATVI in an all-cash deal valued at $68.7 billion.

What's happening

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA dropped 496 points, or 1.4%, to 35,416.

The S&P 500 SPX was down 69 points, or 1.5%, at 4,594.

The Nasdaq Composite COMP fell 292 points, or 2%, to 14,602.

Last week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each lost ground, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq now down 5% for the year.

What's driving markets

The big move in financial markets Tuesday was in bonds, as the yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 5.6 basis points to 1.846%, its highest since January 2020.

Yields on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Y, which are more sensitive to Fed policy expectations, shot up 7 basis points, rising above 1% for the first time since early 2020, according to FactSet.

Yield-sensitive tech and other growth stocks were weighing on the Nasdaq, but “it is not all doom and gloom out there, because M&A activity is going well, and the ongoing vaccination efforts by Western governments means the soft patch in U.S. and global data could be short-lived,” said Fawad Razaqzada, analyst at ThinkMarkets, in a note.

The week will feature quarterly reports from 35 companies in the S&P 500 index. Goldman Sachs Group Inc.GS on Tuesday said its fourth-quarter profit fell 13%, missing Wall Street estimates, in a choppy quarter for the Wall Street firm. Shares of the Dow component dropped 8%, leading losses for the blue-chip gauge.

Crude-oil prices CL00, meanwhile, traded at their highest since 2014 after Middle East unrest, after Houthi rebels launched a drone attack on a key oil facility in Abu Dhabi. The United Arab Emirates is OPEC's third-largest producer.

The New York Fed's Empire State index of business conditions nosedived to -0.7 in January from 31.9 in the prior month, reflecting fresh strains from the omicron virus and ongoing supply-chain bottlenecks.

Which companies are in focus?

In its biggest ever acquisition, MicrosoftMSFT said it would pay $95 per ActivisionATVI share to create the world's third-biggest gaming company measured by revenue, behind Tencent and Sony. Microsoft shares fell 1.5%, while Activision surged nearly 28%.

Other videogame companies also jumped, with Electronic Arts Inc.EA up 5.8 and Take-Two Interactive Software Inc.TTWO rising 3.8%.

Shares of Charles Schwab Corp.SCHW fell 3.5% after the online brokerage reported earnings and revenue that came in below Wall Street forecasts.

Shares of Plexus Corp.PLXS were lower after the electronic manufacturing services company warned that it will miss fiscal first-quarter profit and revenue guidance provided in October because of “unanticipated” supply chain challenges that worsened in the finals weeks of the quarter.

How other assets are trading

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, rose 0.5%.

Gold futures GC00 edged lower, down 0.2%.

The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP fell 0.8%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX was down 0.4%.

The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP rose 0.8%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI was down 0.4% in Hong Kong and the Nikkei 225 JP:NIK off 0.3%.
